My piece "Restful Rhino", 60 by 50 inches, edition of 10. Two other sizes are available.  In this beautiful loft. Let me know what you think in the comments below! 

In this series, Zilberberg creates animal montages as an expression of self-therapy, drawing attention to mindfulness and nature conservation. As an urbanite, functioning day-to-day in a fast-paced, built environment can be emotionally unsettling. The artist regrounds herself in the sense of calm issued by these animals. These creatures reinstate a presence, a tranquility, and a grander perspective. Their minimal aesthetic is metaphorical of striving for simplicity. Zilberberg’s works invite a meditative state, encouraging the viewer to stay still and find happiness in the moment.

#artgalleries #artadvisor #artdealer #artgalleries #newcontemporary #modernartwork #artadvisory #alicezilberberg

Today I want to share something I haven't shared on here yet. I think it's the right time for me to share with you, my audience, what I've been going through.

Three years ago today, my only brother, Anton, died suddenly from a heart attack. He was 33, there were no signs. He appeared and felt healthy. It happened on a camping trip with his wife and two kids. 

A few months ago, my dad, who was 62, died by suicide. This came as a shock to everyone. I had no idea he was planning this. 

Just like that, one day, they were gone. 

Following what happened with my brother, I listened to my heart and made the decision to move back to Israel, the place where we grew up. After living in Canada for 20 years, I changed my whole life. 

After these events, I developed more of an inclination to follow my heart no matter my surroundings. I've always done this; that's how I became an artist. I always had the sense that life is fragile, that I have to be what I'm meant to be, and that material things and money are not the real value of this place we live in. Even more so now, only good things have come from listening to my inner-knowing, and doing everything, for myself and for others, with love. 

I will never stop creating because I believe that's what I was placed on here to do: to show the beauty of nature. Not only that it's beautiful, but that we, human beings, are a part of it. I think it's no coincidence that spending time in nature often brings an inner-peace. Maybe a few generations from now, people will look at my work, and these scenes will no longer be tangible.

Nature is magical. It is powerful. Art is powerful. If I have touched anyone with my work, I am grateful. 

#fineartphotographer #animalartists #contemporaryphoto #contemporaryartcollector #wildlifeartwork #artcollecting #artwatchers #minimalphotography #alicezilberberg

This is a piece I made in 2018. The model, my friend, Dor, is one of the people they murdered in the terrorist attack on October 7th. His girlfriend and him were in a party near Nirim in the south of Israel, they were both murdered.

I don't think it's a coincidence that I made this piece, and that I named it "This is your Life Now". I've thought of him every day since I heard. Dor is a beautiful soul, with a big heart, and I hope that he is in a beautiful place now.

ABOUT THE ARTWORK

In this series, Zilberberg creates animal montages as an expression of self-therapy. As an urbanite, functioning day-to-day in a fast-paced, built environment can be emotionally unsettling. The artist regrounds herself in the sense of calm issued by these animals. These creatures reinstate a presence, a tranquility, and a grander perspective. The works are an amalgam of many photographs from different locations around the world, put together seamlessly by the artist in post-production. Their minimal aesthetic is metaphorical of striving for simplicity. Rather than ruminating on the past, or hypothesizing the future, Zilberberg’s works invite a meditative state, encouraging the viewer to stay still and find happiness in the moment.
